text:
What do folks consider to be the difference between *Content Marketing* and *Product Marketing?* Particularly in terms of first hires at a startup or in a growing marketing organization.

For example - both generate collateral, and written material, to support the story of the product/business/service.

In both, you're defining a narrative and a story.

How do you differentiate the two?

elements.text: What do folks consider to be the difference between
Content Marketing
and
Product Marketing?

Particularly in terms of first hires at a startup or in a growing marketing organization.

For example - both generate collateral, and written material, to support the story of the product/business/service.

In both, you're defining a narrative and a story.

How do you differentiate the two?

text:
There’s a lot of collaboration between these two groups, and depending on the company and the team, there’s probably major overlap, but here’s been my experience:
*Content Marketing:* Focused on telling the story of the company from a high-level. They do a lot of brand work. They *should be* in charge of content strategy/editorial calendars, so they’re planning for each piece of content that goes out, even product pieces. But they may not write the pieces themselves.
Examples of general collateral/written material: annual reports, e-books, website changes, case studies, etc.
*Product Marketing:* Focused on telling the story of a product. Work very closely with the product engineers. They become a type of SME on a product, themselves.
Examples of general collateral/written material: annual reports, e-books, website changes, case studies, product tours, product 1-pagers, etc.

If you notice there’s a ton of overlap between the two for collateral and written material…it’s because there is!

Here’s it often happened on my teams. If a product is launching, the content marketing team works closely with product marketing to determine how the new product fits into the larger narrative. Content marketing develops a content plan (we’ll want to announce the new product on our website, we’ll want a quick, instructional video, we’ll plan a case study featuring a customer who’s been using it, we’ll write a couple of TOFU blogs, etc.), then they work with product marketing to develop these content pieces. Some product marketers are writers and will write some of these pieces. Other product marketers will collaborate with a writer on the content team to develop these pieces.

This isn’t a hard-and-fast rule, but I’d say content marketers do a lot with TOFU content, and Product Marketing often work with more BOFU content. They also dabble a little bit in sales enablement because sales teams need and love to know about the products they’re selling. :slightly_smiling_face:

I hope that makes sense! Feel free to reach out with any questions.

Examples of general collateral/written material: annual reports, e-books, website changes, case studies, product tours, product 1-pagers, etc.

If you notice there’s a ton of overlap between the two for collateral and written material…it’s because there is!

Here’s it often happened on my teams. If a product is launching, the content marketing team works closely with product marketing to determine how the new product fits into the larger narrative. Content marketing develops a content plan (we’ll want to announce the new product on our website, we’ll want a quick, instructional video, we’ll plan a case study featuring a customer who’s been using it, we’ll write a couple of TOFU blogs, etc.), then they work with product marketing to develop these content pieces. This isn’t a hard-and-fast rule, but I’d say content marketers do a lot with TOFU content, and Product Marketing often work with more BOFU content. They also dabble a little bit in sales enablement because sales teams need and love to know about the products they’re selling.
I hope that makes sense! Feel free to reach out with any questions.

text: i sort of think of product marketing as content marketing without the vanity metrics :laughing:

elements.text: i sort of think of product marketing as content marketing without the vanity metrics

text:
I worked at a company that raise a ton of money and our head of marketing came from a product marketing background. his entire focus was about nailing the product messaging / positioning, building relationships with key customers and analysts, and working with our PR agency to tell the company story.

then he left and a head of demand generation came in. he quickly realized that we had done zero SEO-focused content even though we had a full-time content hire. we didn’t have any solid lead programs generating pipeline. and our salesforce was a mess.

that was a great early experience in my career that showed the difference between the two. I think of product marketing as the long term focused activities that you can’t really ever measure (nor should) and content marketing as one of the parts of a marketing team that is more measurable and focused.

obviously that’s a simplified take and i’m sure tons of people will carve out caveats. but thought I’d share my first-hand experience!

elements.text:

then he left and a head of demand generation came in. he quickly realized that we had done zero SEO-focused content even though we had a full-time content hire. we didn’t have any solid lead programs generating pipeline. and our salesforce was a mess.

that was a great early experience in my career that showed the difference between the two. I think of product marketing as the long term focused activities that you can’t really ever measure (nor should) and content marketing as one of the parts of a marketing team that is more measurable and focused.

obviously that’s a simplified take and i’m sure tons of people will carve out caveats. but thought I’d share my first-hand experience!

text: I'd say that at our org, it's pretty close to Ashly's description. Our product marketer works on stuff like case studies, posts on how to use new product features, in-product tutorials and liaises with the product team as well as support to identify pain points that she can create content around — so it's marketing to existing customers so that they can get the most out of our product, or creating content that helps people in trial move along the funnel. Content marketing for us, on the other hand, is more focused on generating net new leads (so SEO, downloadable assets about more thought-leadership-y topics that are less tied to using the product).

Content marketing for us, on the other hand, is more focused on generating net new leads (so SEO, downloadable assets about more thought-leadership-y topics that are less tied to using the product).

text:
I wrote about this kind of recently, and my admittedly reductionist elevator pitch/rule of thumb that we use to help clients understand is:
• *Content marketing*: what does your audience want to know?
• *Product marketing*: what do you want your audience to know about you?

elements.text: I wrote about this kind of recently, and my admittedly reductionist elevator pitch/rule of thumb that we use to help clients understand is:
Content marketing
: what does your audience want to know?
Product marketing
: what do you want your audience to know about you?

text:
Agree with the majority of what's been said above. Ashley's description is similar to how the two roles function at my work. A few things to also note:
• I think many folks who get a bit confused about are outside stakeholders (ex: I had other managers and directors asking about the relationship) 
• I also feel as though product marketing managers inherently work closer with the product + sales teams as some of their primary stakeholders to support (whereas content marketing are collaborating with paid media, social, etc.) 
• Spot on about editorial calendars, content production, amplification plans. Typically the product marketing manager is not leading these activities or even having a strong voice
A few tips from my experience:
• Make sure both the product marketing manager and content marketing manager know what they are responsible for leading vs. what they will provide feedback or input on
• Make sure other stakeholders are aware of the differences in functions
• Always collaborate - the content larger strategy needs to include both elements

Always collaborate - the content larger strategy needs to include both elements
